ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Three-dimensional structure of polystyrene colloidal crystal by synchrotron radiation X-ray phase-contrast computed tomography

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Colloidal crystal with long-range ordered structure has attracted great attention for their applications in various fields. Although perfect colloidal crystals have been achieved by some fabrications for utilization, little is known about their exact structures and internal defects. In this study, we use synchrotron radiation (SR) phase-contrast computed tomography (CT) to noninvasively access the internal structure of polystyrene (PS) colloidal crystals in three dimensions (3D). The phase-attenuation duality Paganin algorithm phase retrieval was employed to achieve a satisfactory contrast and outline of the spheres. After CT reconstruction, the positions of individual PS particles and structural defects are identified in three dimensions, and the local crystal structure is revealed. Further quantitative analysis of the void system in colloidal crystal illustrates that single voids can be mostly attributed to tetrahedron void of sphere close packing, but the interconnected voids with large volume induce a sphere volume fraction of 59.39 % that reflects a metastable glass behavior of colloidal crystal arrangement. The void orientation result reveals that the 3D close-packing difficulty mainly lies in the stacking of interlayer.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Colloidal crystals, which are three-dimensionally (3D) periodic lattices with some arrangement mode of monodisperse colloidal spheres, have attracted great attention for application in various technical fields [1]. In optical application, colloidal crystals are expected to be used as photonic band gap crystals with a band gap that excludes propagation of electromagnetic wave of a chosen range of frequencies [2, 3]. In other fields, colloidal crystals have been exploited as a model system to study the transition mechanism of some structural phases [4], and provided a potentially useful route for porous catalysts [5], separation technology [6], absorption [7], solar cells [8], and so on.

The colloidal crystal fabricated by self-assembly always has drawbacks, mainly in the intrinsic disorder present in the structures [9, 10] and the difficulty of importing functional defects at desired positions [11]. Although it has been shown that selective incorporation of defects is possible, defect growth resulted in a decrease in the degree of orderliness [12] or required some complex post-processing [13]. A theoretical calculation illustrating that thermodynamically stable crystalline phase for colloidal crystal arrangement is face-centered cubic (fcc) structure, and the Gibbs free energy difference between hexagonal close packing and fcc is only 0.005RT [14], so self-assembly often results in a mixture of the two structures, which is unfavorable for the device properties. To fully understand the connections between the exact 3D structure and the growth process and finally control the resulting structure and the interior defect of colloidal crystal, detailed knowledge about the local internal structure has to be obtained.

The common techniques for colloidal crystal structure generally have some limitations. Scanning electron microscopy as a surface method cannot obtain the internal structure of a sample [15, 16]. Small-angle X-ray scattering [17] and transmission/reflection spectrum [18] provide the entirely average information of the crystal structure but neglect the detailed arrangement such as the local defect, which is important for the optical properties and growth process [19]. To study the local structure in three dimensions, confocal microscopy [4, 20] was used by some studies for measurement of the 3D arrangement of colloidal particles. But the particles are required to be labeled to make them visible with fluorescence microscopy, and the space among the particles has to be infiltrated with a refractive index matching liquid to prevent the scattering of visible lights [4]. That possibly alters the grown crystal structure. Accordingly, a noninvasive and in situ characterization technique is in need for learning the local internal structure of colloidal crystal in three dimensions. Recent developments in synchrotron radiation (SR) X-ray imaging have the potential to access the internal structure of colloidal crystals. The relatively high penetrability of hard X-ray enables noninvasive studies of almost any material and thickness. Moreover, the high degree of (lateral) coherence of the SR sources allows implementation of phase-contrast imaging (PCI) techniques. Many research results have revealed that PCI can provide satisfactory image contrast for low-absorption materials with small density differences, such as alveoli [21], cavernous hemangioma of the liver [22], and polystyrene/polyethylene foams [23].

In this paper, the local internal structure of polystyrene (PS) colloidal crystal fabricated by gravity sedimentation was revealed by SR X-ray phase-contrast computed tomography (CT) technology. By phase retrieval, CT reconstruction and quantitative analysis, the 3D stacking structure of PS particles was extracted, the distribution and orientation of void system were calculated, and further the growth and structure characteristics of colloidal crystal were discussed.

Section2.Heading: Phase retrieval (PR)
Section2.Para: X-ray imaging detectors are sensitive to intensity modulations, the absorption and phase shift information can both be embedded in the recorded images; and the absorption parts are nearly the same for low density sample and the background. Furthermore, the phase information cannot be accessed directly without any further processing. So it requires the phase-retrieval processing to extract the phase information.

When the sample fulfills the assumption on its properties: the absorption is weak and the sample is homogenous, the real and imaginary parts of n − 1 are proportional to each other: 5

Based on the PAD property and weak absorption of the sample, the single sample-to-detector distance (SDD) phase-retrieval algorithms could be employed for extracting the phase information.

Section2.Heading: Samples
Section2.Para: 2.5 % solids (w/v) aqueous suspension of polystyrene sphere (Polysciences Inc., USA) was used. To acquire a capillary, the top of a 10 μl pipet tip (Fisherbrand, China) was hot-melt, drawn and then sealed. Before assembly, the capillaries used as the containers were firstly immersed in absolute ethyl alcohol and then dried in an oven. The suspension was treated in an ultrasonic instrument for 10 min for uniform distribution of the PS spheres in the medium. To prepare the PS colloidal crystals by gravity sedimentation method, drops of the suspension were added into the capillary, and bathed in a water thermostat to keep a given temperature of 50 °C. Then, it was settled for sedimentation of the PS spheres under gravity and the evaporation of the medium.

Section2.Heading: Image acquisition and reconstruction
Section2.Para:
The X-ray phase-contrast experiment was performed at the beamline BL13W1 of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility in China, which is a third-generation synchrotron radiation facility with stable electron beam current of 210 mA and 3.5 GeV storage ring energy. The beamline BL13W1 could offer X-ray energy from 8 to 72.5 keV, and the samples were set approximately 34 m from the wiggler source. The schematic outline of the setup for in-line phase-contrast CT is shown in Fig. 1. The incident monochromatic X-ray was obtained through a Si double-crystal monochromator, and then passed through the sample. Subsequently, the transmitted X-ray beam was acquired and recorded by an X-ray sensitive detector with 200 μm thick YAG: Ce scintillator and PCO 2000 CCD (2,048 × 2,048 pixels). The pixel size of the CCD is 7.4 μm and a 40× objective lens was coupled. The distance from the sample to the detector could be adjusted along a rail.
Fig. 1
Schematic outline of SR X-ray phase-contrast CT

During the CT data acquisition, the colloidal crystal sample was mounted on a 6D assembled Kohzu stage. The data set contains 900 projections. Each projection was taken in 0.2° steps, for a half-turn between 0° and 180°. Two flat field images were also captured between every 30° rotation and five dark current images were acquired at the end to normalize the projections. Then, the PITRE V3.1 software [33] was adopted for phase retrieval with PAD-PA and for slice reconstruction with Gridrec algorithm [34]. Meanwhile, the Shepp–Logan filter was utilized to suppress noise; the ring artifact correction was also carried out.

Section2.Para:

where I max and I min are the maximum and minimum intensities measured in the selected region of interest (ROI), respectively. The ROIs were set at the sphere region with a square shape of 151 pixels × 151 pixels.

Visualization and analysis for voids among the PS spheres were performed by software Blob 3D [35]. As the sample is cylindrical, a ROI of 348 × 349 pixels lying in the top left quarter of the whole slice was extracted for further analysis. 1,400 slices for the close-packing region of spheres were all involved. The selected volume of colloidal crystal was segmented by threshold, which was selected according to the known diameter of the PS sphere. Then, Blob 3D was used to identify and measure the contiguous regions of pixels (‘blobs’) that are connected in 3D. Each set represents a single void, or connected voids. Void volume fraction was defined as the number of void voxels divided by the total number of selected volume voxels. The orientation of the 3D void system was calculated according to the star volume distribution (SVD) method by software Quant3D [36].

Section2.Heading: SR phase-contrast imaging
Section2.Para:
To find the proper imaging parameters for PCI, the PS colloidal crystal was imaged at different energies (E = 9, 12, 15 keV) and varied sample-to-detector distances (SDD = 0.7, 4, 8, 13 cm), respectively. Figure 2 reveals the SR projections at 12 keV with different SDDs. Figure 2a displays the colloidal crystal image taken at 0.7 cm. Obviously, the image shows little contrast for spheres in the capillary that is because the absorption term possesses most proportion. As the SDD rises, shown in Fig. 2b–d, the image contrast enhances visibly, and the overlapped spheres with some voids exhibiting a worm-like appearance are clearly seen. Moreover, along with increasing SDD, the phase shift information was enhancing so as to see the increasing edge-enhancement effect.

Section2.Heading: 3D colloidal crystal structure
Section2.Para: Sedimentation in a gravitational field seems to be the simplest approach to the formation of 3D crystalline arrays from colloidal spheres. Actually, it involves a strong coupling of several complex processes such as gravitational settling, translational diffusion (or Brownian motion), and crystallization (nucleation and growth) [1]. The success of this method relies on tight control over the rate of sedimentation. The 3D arrays produced are often polycrystalline.

Figure 5a depicts a selected ROI lying in the top left quarter of the whole slice image reconstructed from the phase-retrieved projections, from which we extracted the particle positions (Fig. 5b) to observe the stacking structures of colloidal crystal. As shown in Fig. 5b–d, the positions extracted were colored in red, green, and blue, respectively, for the three sequential particle layers. The stacking density from the bottom right to the top left is decreasing, because the particle sedimentation speed at the top left is restrained by the wall of sample chamber. The PS spheres tended to form a close-packing structure with little void, but still with some defects and inhomogeneous packing styles which induces a reducing particle volume fraction. Shown in Fig. 5b, two typical vacancies were indicated by arrows. Here, particles may have been slightly above or below this tomographic slice, because the faster stacking speed made these particles to not have enough time to locate at a suitable position in this layer. Moreover, the right one did not gain an adequate seat space due to its only five neighboring particles. The stacking pattern is correlated with that of the neighboring particles. At the top part of this image, there exists a transition from square lattice to hexagonal lattice structure. Particle e has nine nearest neighbor particles, particle f has six, and the intermediate ones are all accompanied with seven. General arguments suggest that crystallization may proceed by a square lattice structure as a metastable state. With regard to the assembly process, the faster sedimentation led to a square-hexagonal multi-domain structure. But the metastable square packing possesses a tendency to hexagonal lattice through decreasing the neighboring particles due to the entropy-driven phase transition. The registration between subsequent close-packed layers determines the resultant crystal structure. The positions of the three sequential layers can clearly be seen in the aggregate position-extracted image shown in Fig. 5e. Both well-arranged areas and the defect features are evident. As rectangle-marked, two areas show regions of face-centered cubic (ABC… sequence, fcc) structure. Although the slice images (Fig. 5b–d) indicate a close packing 2D layer, the most part of stacking between the layers is disordered. It is represented as that most particles do not occupy the central vacant positions among the particles of the previous layer, thus the disorderliness of colloidal crystal assembly mainly exists in the interlayer arrangement.

3D visualization of the structure for PS colloidal crystal from the slice data is shown in Fig. 6a and b. They are representative binary renderings corresponding to physical dimensions of 0.06 mm × 0.06 mm × 0.025 mm for sphere and void structure, respectively. The PS spheres stack closely and contact each other partly, following some independent and interconnected voids. Quantitative analysis of the void system in the selected quarter volume of 348 × 349 × 1,400 pixels is presented in Fig. 6c and Table 1 is the total statistics result. A total of 469 voids were extracted and measured, with volume ranging larger than 10−11 mm3. As seen the void volume distribution, the void volume between 10−10 and 10−9 mm3 is the main class including nearly half of all the voids (49.25 %). That is followed by the voids of 10−11–10−10 mm3 (28.14 %) and 10−9–10−8 mm3 (19.40 %), and they are all single voids. For the adopted PS sphere in this research, the volume of tetrahedron void originated from sphere close packing is calculated to be 4 × 10−10 mm3 that exactly locates in the range of the main volume class. This illustrates that most of the voids could be attributed to the close-packing pattern of spheres. Voids of larger volume only account for 3.20 % in all the voids, which illustrates just limited number of the interconnected large void in the assembled colloidal crystal. However, in view of the void volume fraction, the interconnected voids possess the major volume portion of all the voids. It shows that most colloidal spheres tended to arrange with some kind of defect, such as, vacancy, dislocation, and so on, which all induced a decreasing sphere volume fraction to be 59.39 %, shown in Table 1. As we know, the phase behavior is determined solely by the volume fraction [38], and the maximum packing volume fraction of 3D monodisperse sphere array is 74 %. When the volume fraction is between 58 and 63 %, the crystallization of the colloids can be arrested by the appearance of a metastable, kinetically trapped state known as a glass [38]. In the preparation of PS colloidal crystal sample by gravity sedimentation, the environmental conditions were not controlled tightly causing a fast and instable rate of sedimentation, so most particles did not have enough time to explore a proper position for crystallization that led to the non-equilibrium assembly behavior as a glass.

Figure 6d, e shows the different views of a 3D rose diagram calculated with SVD method, which reflects the void orientation of the colloidal crystal. The view through the up-down axis (Fig. 6d) suggests an orientation along the secondary eigenvector u2 component about 50° clockwise from the main fabric. Because the selected volume for SVD calculation is the top left quarter part of the whole slice, this void orientation shows that at horizontal plane the maximal developed radius of a void approximately pointed to the circle center of the capillary cross section. From the view of an arbitrary orientation (Fig. 6e), the rose diagram indicates that the void system grew stronger vertically than laterally, suggesting the shape anisotropy of the voids with a primary axis pointing predominantly vertically. The analysis illustrates that in the 3D growth process of colloidal crystal, the sphere stacking between two layers was less close than that of interior of a layer. That once again testifies for colloidal spheres in self-assembly, that it is more difficult to locate at a central vacancy on the previous layer, so the main obstacle for integrated 3D close packing lies in the interlayer stacking.

As the SR X-ray possesses the high penetrability, the CT method for noninvasive in situ 3D structure imaging could be developed to other porous bulk materials, such as inorganic frame, photonic crystal, etc. especially in the field of the internal structure confirmation, and functional defect detection.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: The 3D internal structure of colloidal crystal was noninvasively detected by SR X-ray CT method together with phase-contrast imaging on a single-particle level. The phase retrieval based on PAD-PA and then data reconstruction were used to the set of projections for the slice images with distinct contrast and outline. For a ROI, the positions and stacking structure of individual particles were extracted; the crystal defects and structures were identified. Quantitative analysis of the void system in the colloidal crystal illustrates a sphere volume fraction of 59.39 % as a non-equilibrium assembly behavior of glass. The void orientation result based on the SVD calculation reveals that the void anisotropy points to predominantly vertical direction, indicating the difficulty of interlayer stacking. In the near future, we will extend our studies to include the temporal evolution of colloid crystal formation and the structure of building bulks with more complex shapes and fabrication technology where more intriguing behavior is expected.
